Posts.Content: Educate yourself.  Does your mammogram report whether your breasts are dense?  www.areyoudenseadvocacy.org This site is about " giving women with dense breast tissue access to early detection."  Check it out and see if your state mandates density information on your mammogram results. You may need more conclusive testing than a mammogram.
Posts.Title: So what advice do you have about my 'biopsy" or lack there of...

Posts.Content: On Sep 13, 2014 2:14 PM alabamagirl wrote: I just went in yesterday for another mammogram and sonogram. I feel a very painful lump about the size of a half of a Ping pong ball and another smaller lump near it. The techs said they could feel it but not see anything. If we can all feel something, then I'm not crazy and there's something there that doesn't belong! 2 years ago I went through the same thing. I went in with a surgeon for a third opinion and he said it was normal breast tissue. Am I crazy in thinking normal breast tissue should not feel like a large and now a small lump and hurt? I feel like I'm a hypochondriac, but it hurts and it's not normal whatever it is. My doctor should be calling me on Monday with the results after the images are read by a radiologist. I'm not sure what to do if the come back negative, knowing that there's something there. :( This reply isn't totally on-topic with the thread here but just want to let you know, alabamagirl, that you aren't alone. I also have a tender, painful lump area in one breast along with a small, roundish spot near the midline (same breast).  My mamm reports always come back stating I have dense breast tissue.  My gyn has never suggested a sonogram and this week I called her office, complained to the nurse, got an appointment (Fri, 9/19), she checked me, and then made an appointment for me (Wed, 9/24) for a unilateral diagnostic mammogram and a sonogram.  It's my understanding that a diagnostitician can only rule out cancer completely with a biopsy.  Visual interpretation from mamm/sono-grams and MRI's can strongly suggest cysts, density, calcifications, etc but a core needle biopsy may be between 97-100% accurate in giving a diagnosis.  I hope you get answers soon.  Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: Time to be pro-active. Don't wait for the scheduler to set up the biopsy appointment, Jenny...you go ahead, call the office, and state your case, and tell them when you're available.  The 2nd round of mammograms took more views than the January visit so consider it helpful, more conclusive and not a time waste. :) I went through the same kind of experience (2 sets of mamms, no ultrasound) and finally saw a breast specialist who helped me understand more about breast density that makes imaging a challenge to 'read'.  Good luck and let us know how it goes!
Posts.Title: BIRADS 4 - suspicious abnormality

Posts.Content: How did the stereotactic biopsy go? Results in?
Posts.Title: BIRADS 4 - suspicious abnormality

Posts.Content: The idea is that a cancer diagnosis is not an automatic death sentence within a given timeline anymore. With early-mid late diagnosis and treatment options available today the treatment kicks cancer ass or keeps it contained to a minimum which, with regular appointments and scans almost makes it like a chronic condition. Emphasis is on longevity.  That's my understanding at least.   Good news?  Yes, to see cancer as a pesky chronic condition to stay on top of and defeat.  My husband views it that way!
Posts.Title: Good news !

Posts.Content: On Jan 20, 2015 8:15 PM Hussy wrote: I'm so sorry to hear about your diagnosis.  Obviously this is not the news for which you were hoping.  MD Anderson is an excellent choice -- the only NCI-rated Comprehensive Cancer Center in Texas.  I hope you can get into see someone at MD Anderson very soon.  You'll feel better when you have a plan of action.  Keep us posted as you can.  Sending good thoughts your way.The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center is NCI designated as Comprehensive Cancer Center. UT Southwestern Medical Center (UTSW) - Simmons Cancer Center in Dallas, University of Texas Health Science Center in San Antonio, and Baylor College of Medicine in Houston are also NCI recognized. Questions? Check it out at the bottom page paragraph. http://www.cancer.gov/researchandfunding/extramural/cancerce
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Gigi56 - are you saying there are 3 generations of breast cancer in your daughter's immediate family including you? That would put your daughter into a  'high risk' group for breast cancer and certainly that qualifies her for a breast MRI and/or fine needle aspiration of both cyst and possibly the 'fibroid'. Mom, do you carry a breast cancer gene?  http://www.cancer.org/cancer/cancercauses/geneticsandcancer/ check out the section on Hereditary breast cancer Good luck.
Posts.Title: Normal Mammo and ultrasound
33 years old - multiple lumps - family history

Posts.Content: Henda's Law is in effect in Texas, Connecticut, New York, and Virginia.  If your mammogram detects dense breast tissue {which can hide abnormalities} you will see this on the mailed mammogram report and you may benefit from other screening tests as needed.  Other states are working on legislation for Henda's Law to pass also.  Check out this link for much more information. http://areyoudenseadvocacy.org/
Posts.Title: ultrasound for breast cancer!

Posts.Content: Maybe you need a 3-d mammogram that would show details of breast density without overlapping tissue. Still have periods? The aches/pains maybe tied to hormonal shifts...and last but not least, do you consume alot of caffeine? Most of all have a sit-down discussion with your pcp or gynecologist and go over your mammogram results along with family history specifics. I'd go for the 3-d mamm.Health insurance currently won't cover....I'm planning on one next year and will pay for it myself if necessary. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Mammogram was clear
